audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 1. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Books for Unit 23 and Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 23 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Mudslide.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the comparative and superlative suffixes -er and -est, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /fffaaassst/, fast. /fffaaassstûûûrrr/, faster. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.' Say the word nice and loud.
Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Suffixes "er" and "est" are used to compare things.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "fast." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "fast." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "fast" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "faster" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Faster. <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: a rabbit is faster than a turtle.
Now add the suffix "est" to the end of the word "fast." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "fast" across from the phonics/syllable card "est" and the word "fastest" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Fastest. <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: the cheetah is the fastest animal on land.
Practice adding suffixes "er" and "est" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words: tall, short, long, sad twice each, once across from the "er" phonics/syllable card and once across from the "est" phonics/syllable card>

audio.transcription: Write one sentence using an "er" word and one sentence using an "est" word from the list.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about rainforests disappearing. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. trees <pause>, rainforest <pause>, clearing. Look at the picture of the rainforest. What do you notice about the trees?
audio.notes: visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about rainforests disappearing. The word is release. Release means “let go or let out.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, release>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words release and eliminated>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Why Are Rainforests Disappearing?”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about rainforests disappearing? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this story is "A Visit to the Rainforest.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: A Visit to the Rainforest. In this story, the narrator, or person telling the story, visits a tropical rainforest in the country of Costa Rica.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: explore. Explore means to travel through a place to learn more about it. Astronauts traveled into space to explore the moon. What are some places you would like to explore?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, explore>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find two words with the suffi x -est that describe a tropical rainforest.
What animals did the narrator, or person telling the story, see in the rainforest? Find the sentences that answer the question.
Why did the narrator and Dad need a guide to help them explore the rainforest? Why did they explore this place during the daytime and at night?
What is a place that you would like to explore? Explain your answer.
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: Write what you would be most excited to see if you explored a rainforest. <pause> Share your ideas with a partner before you write. Look back at the story for ideas.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 2. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 1 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the story “A Visit to the Rainforest.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

audio.transcription: Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: covered, cried, figure, horse, money.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word cried. Say the word with me. Cried. What sounds do you hear in cried? (/k/ /r/ /i/ /d/) Blend the sounds together.
What letters do you see? (c-r-i-e-d) This is the past tense of cry. Notice how you change the y to i before adding the -ed ending, just like in tried and fried.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: covered, figure, horse, money.

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Add Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say a word: in. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /th/
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Add the sound /th/ to the beginning of the word in. What's the new word? <pause> thin
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's add a sound to the end of a word. Listen as I say a word: win. <slight pause> Now, listen as I say a sound: /d/
Add the sound /d/ to the end of the word win. What's the new word? <pause> wind
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "clean." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "clean." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "clean" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "cleaner" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Cleaner. <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: Jan's room is cleaner than Greg's room.
Now add the suffix "est" to the end of the word "clean." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "clean" across from the phonics/syllable card "est" and the word "cleanest" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Cleanest. <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: the kitchen is the cleanest room in our house.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the comparative and superlative suffixes -er and -est, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Listen as I sound out the first two words.
audio.notes: <visual: show blend words table>

audio.transcription: /fffaaassst/, fast. /fffaaassstûûûrrr/, faster. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.' Say the word nice and loud.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about Earth’s land biomes. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. desert <pause>, grassland <pause>, savanna <pause>, rainforest. Look at the pictures of the desert, savanna, grassland, and rainforest. Can you point out the different animals and plants in the pictures?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about Earth’s land biomes. The word is types. Types means “kinds.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, types>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words types and receive>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Exploring Earth’s Land Biomes”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about Earth’s land biomes? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this text is "The Power of Trees.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Power of Trees. This text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue. This text explains how trees help keep our air clean.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: preserve. Preserve means to keep something from being harmed or destroyed. Many people work to preserve habitats for plants and animals. That’s where plants and animals live. How could you preserve an item that is special to you?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, preserve>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that means the same as biggest.
What do forests do with carbon dioxide? Why is this good for the air? Find the sentences that answer these questions.
Why is it important to preserve, or protect, Earth’s forests? What might happen if we do not preserve trees?
What information would you share with people to help them understand the importance of protecting Earth’s trees?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List three to five facts you learned about the power of trees and the effects of destroying forests. <pause> Draw a picture to accompany your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 3. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 2 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Power of Trees” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 2 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "sweet." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "sweet." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "sweet" across from the phonics/syllable card "er" and the word "sweeter" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Sweeter. <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: The honey is sweeter than the peanut butter.
Now add the suffix "est" to the end of the word "sweet." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "sweet" across from the phonics/syllable card "est" and the word "sweetest" underneath them>

audio.transcription: Sweetest. <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: The orange is the sweetest food in my lunch.

Blend Words: Now that we’ve learned about the comparative and superlative suffixes -er and -est, let’s blend some words using these suffixes and other word parts and sounds we have learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with -er.
Now, let's put a box around all the words with -est.

Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word new. <pause> Add the letters er to make a comparative adjective. What word did you make? Newer
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word new <pause>. Now change new to newer. Which sound is different? Which letters are different?

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with the comparative suffixes -er and -est and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 12-13>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with the comparative suffixes -er and -est. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word stronger. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word stronger>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: older/oldest, smaller/smallest.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs older/oldest, smaller/smallest>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 4. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 3 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 3 spread>

audio.transcription: Introduce High-Frequency Words. Let's learn some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: products, questions, since, usually>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word usually. Slowly clap and say the syllables in the word "usually." u-su-al-ly. We have to pay extra attention to remember its spelling.
Spell the word with me: u-s-u-a-l-l-y.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Focus on the spelling of each part of the word separately.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: products, questions, since.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word strong.
Now write the words stronger and strongest.
Spelling Booster: Let's write some more words. Listen to each word I say. Break apart the word sound by sound, then write the letter or spelling for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Spelling Booster image>

audio.transcription: easier
easiest
longer
longest
bigger
biggest

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things.
Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Then, read each word as your teacher taps on it.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this text is "What Makes a Rainbow?" Point to each word as you read the title with me: What Makes a Rainbow? The title of this text asks a question. This is a poem. The text is formatted in short lines instead of paragraphs. Read the poem. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Find all the words in the poem with comparaitve and superlative suffixes -er and -est and circle them. <pause> Chorally read the circled words.
Write the sentence I say. Listen carefully and focus on one word at a time.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: The first sentence is: The horse ran faster than the fastest goat. Say the sentence with me: The horse ran faster than the fastest goat. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you segment, or break apart, each word and write a letter for each sound.

The second sentence is: Jen’s voice is louder than mine, but Nate’s voice is the loudest of all. Say the sentence with me: Jen’s voice is louder than mine, but Nate’s voice is the loudest of all. Now write the sentence. Your teacher will help you if you need it.
Let's read each sentence out loud. Check your work. Your teacher will write each sentence. Correct your spellings if necessary.
Let's review suffixes. A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word soft and the phonics/syllable card for "er">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "soft." Add the suffix "er" to "soft." What is the new word?
softer. <pause> The suffix "er" can be added to a describing word when comparing two nouns, such as in the sentence: The rug from the store was softer than our rug at home.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word soft and the phonics/syllable card for "er", under them, show the word "softer">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "est" to the end of the word "soft." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word soft and the phonics/syllable card for "est">

audio.transcription: softest. <pause> The suffix "est" can be added to a word to compare more than two nouns such as in the sentence: Tobby was the softest of the four cats.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word soft and the phonics/syllable card for "est", under them, show the word "softest">

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffixes "er" and "est" to the following words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words high, long, wet, and shiny twice, once across from the phonics/syllable card er and once across from the phonics/syllable card est>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 5. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 4 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the story “What Makes a Rainbow?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 4 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about wind. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. kite <pause>, flag <pause>, leaves <pause>, wind turbine. Look at the picture of the kite. What makes a kite fly?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about wind. The word is beneath. Beneath means “below or underneath.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, beneath>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words beneath and invisible>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “An Invisible Force of Nature”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about wind? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this text is "Hurricane Warning!” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Hurricane Warning! You will read about a powerful storm called a hurricane. A hurricane warning lets people know a storm is coming so they can get to a safe place before it arrives.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: severe. Severe means very bad and very serious. During a severe storm, there can be strong winds and heavy rain. What might you see happening outside during a severe storm?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, severe>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find a word in the first paragraph with a suffix that helps you understand that hurricanes are severe storms.
What details show that a hurricane can cause severe destruction, or damage? Find sentences that answer this question.
Why is it important for scientists to forecast, or make predictions about, severe storms like hurricanes?
What would you do to stay safe during a severe storm?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw four boxes on a sheet of paper. <pause> Write Hurricane in the first box as the cause and then draw a picture to show one effect of hurricanes in each remaining box. Use this information to write a short summary of the text. <pause> Share your summary with a partner before writing.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Let's review suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following word: "light." Add the suffix "er" to the end of "light." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "light" and the phonics/syllable card for "er">

audio.transcription: lighter. <pause> The suffix "er" can be added to a describing word when comparing two nouns, such as in the sentence: This box is lighter than the other one.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "light" and the phonics/syllable card for "er", under them, show the word "lighter">

audio.transcription: Now add the suffix "est" to the end of the word "light." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "light" and the phonics/syllable card for "est">

audio.transcription: lightest. <pause> The suffix "est" can be added to a word to compare more than two nouns such as in the sentence: This box is the lightest one of all.
audio.notes: <visual: show the word "light" and the phonics/syllable card for "est", under them, show the word "lightest">

audio.transcription: Practice adding suffixes "er" and "est" to the following words. Remember, you may need to make a spelling change with some words, such as doubling the final consonant, dropping the final "e," or changing the "y" to "i."
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "late," "full," and "pretty" twice, once across from the phonics/syllable card er and once across from the phonics/syllable card est>

audio.transcription: Look at these words. Let's read the words together: busy, busier, busiest, silly, sillier, silliest, safe, safer, safest, deep, deeper, deepest, sad, sadder, saddest. Now look at these two categories. This is the word busy. Read the word with me. <pause> Which category should I put busy under? <pause> Yes, busy goes in the base word category because the word busy has no suffix. With your partner, continue to sort the rest of the words.
audio.notes: <visual: show words busy, busier, busiest, silly, sillier, silliest, safe, safer, safest, deep, deeper, deepest, sad, sadder, saddest> <visual: show word busy> <visual: show the sorting cards base word, er, and est in a pocket chart>

audio.transcription: What did you notice about the words in each group?
The suffixes "-er" and "-est" " are common word parts. You may notice the suffixes "-er" and "-est" in many words. As we read, let's look for words with "-er" and "-est."

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 6. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 5 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the text “Hurricane Warning!” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 1 spread>

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Blend and Segment Multisyllabic Words by Syllable

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following syllables: un-hap-py
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Repeat the syllables and blend them to make a word. un-hap-py, unhappy.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following syllables. Blend the syllables to make a word.
Now we will segment words into syllables. Listen as I say the following word: unhappy
Repeat the word and segment it into the syllables you hear. Unhappy, un-hap-py.
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words. Segment each word into the syllables you hear.

Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Some words need spelling changes when adding a suffix. Listen as I read the following word: "tiny." Before adding suffix "er" to the end of "tiny," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "er." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: tiny tiny-y+i tini+er tinier (please show the "er" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "tinier." <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: The cat is tinier than the dog.
Before adding suffix "est" to the end of "tiny," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "est." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: tiny tiny-y+i tini+est tiniest (please show the "est" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "tiniest." <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: The hamster is the tiniest of all our pets.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Say the sound for each letter or spelling as your teacher points to it. Blend the sounds to read the word. Now read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word covered. Say the word with me: "covered"
Spell the word with me: c-o-v-e-r-e-d. The word "covered" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice.

Build Words Booster: Let's do some more word building. Listen carefully as your teacher tells you which word to make with your letter cards. Your teacher will check your work. Think about each sound in the word you are making. Use letter cards to spell the word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the letter cards to build the words>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Today we are going to read some cumulative sentences. These sentences contain words with -er and -est suffixes and other phonics skills we have learned. Let’s whisper read one sentence at a time. When you are done, we will chorally read them together.
audio.notes: <visual: Show Cumulative Sentences, pages 18-19>

audio.transcription: Circle all the words with -er and -est suffixes. <pause> Turn to a partner and read the words. Your teacher will listen in.
Write a sentence using the word warmest. <pause> When you are finished, read your sentence to a partner.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word warmest>

audio.transcription: Write a sentence using each of these word pairs: colder/coldest, healthier/healthiest.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence strips and word pairs colder/coldest, healthier/healthiest>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 7. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 6 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the cumulative sentences. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 6 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Read: Look at the high-frequency words. Read each word along with me. covered, <pause> cried, <pause> figure, <pause> horse, <pause> money, <pause> products, <pause> questions, <pause> since, <pause> usually, <pause> voice.
audio.notes: <visual: show "covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice" as cards in pocket-chart pockets, add one blank pocket-row, show tray with only letters for the first word.> [intended for teacher to model the first word]

audio.transcription: Build: Now let's build a word together. Watch as your teacher spells the word.
Now use your letter cards to build all the words.
Write: Write each word. Then write a sentence using each word. For example, you can start a sentence with "After school, I usually ______ ." Read your sentences to a partner when you are done.
audio.notes: <visual: show sentence frame "After school, I usually [blank]." Then show "covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice" as cards in pocket-chart pockets underneath sentence frame>

audio.transcription: Now your teacher is going to make a word with letter cards. <pause> What is the word? <pause> Spell it together. <pause> Watch as your teacher scrambles the letters. Fix the spelling.
audio.notes: <visual: empty pocket rows with tray with letter cards for 2nd word>

audio.transcription: Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this text is "What Causes Wind?" Point to the word as you read the title with me: What Causes Wind? This text explains the weather conditions that create wind. It includes a diagram with arrows and labels. Authors include diagrams to help readers understand a series of causes and effects.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: What do you notice or wonder about when viewing the diagram?
Draw a diagram or series of pictures to show another example of a process, such as a seed growing into a plant.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Some words need spelling changes when adding a suffix. Listen as I read the following word: "windy." Before adding suffix "er" to the end of "windy," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "er." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: windy windy-y+i windi+er windier (please show the "er" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "windier." <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: It is windier today than it was yesterday.
Before adding suffix "est" to the end of "windy," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "est." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: windy windy-y+i windi+est windiest (please show the "est" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "windiest." <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: It was the windiest day we've had for months.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's review some high-frequency words. We will Say, Spell, Read, and Write each word.
audio.notes: <visual: e-pocket chart with the following words in this order: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice.>

audio.transcription: Let's start with the word covered. Say the word with me: "covered"
Spell the word with me: c-o-v-e-r-e-d. The word "covered" does not follow the rules. We have to pay extra attention to it to remember its spelling.
Now write the word. Say each letter as you write it. Then, use the word in a sentence.
Now let's Say, Spell, Read, and Write these words: cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice.

toc.title: Morphology: Difference Between Prefixes and Suffixes

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 8. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 7 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the text “What Causes Wind?” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 7 spread>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Let's review comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Some words need spelling changes when adding a suffix. Listen as I read the following word: "thin." Before adding suffix "er" to the end of "thin," first double the final consonant "n." Then add "er." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: thin thin+n+er thinner (please show the "er" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "thinner." <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. For example: The branch is thinner than the tree trunk.
Before adding suffix "est" to the end of "thin," first double the final consonant "n." Then add "est." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: thin thin+n+est thinnest (please show the "est" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "thinnest." <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things. For example: It was the thinnest book on the whole bookshelf.

Blend Words: Let’s blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Sound out the word to yourself. You can whisper it, if you like. Then your teacher will tap on the word again and say ‘altogether.’ Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Let's find and circle all the words with -est.
Now, let's put a box around all the words that are irregular plural nouns.

Blending Focus: Use your letter cards to build each word I say. Let's start by doing one together. Make the word hot. <pause> Add the suffix -er to hot to make a comparative adjective. What spelling change did you make? What word did you make?
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Listen carefully as your teacher tells you the letter or letters to change to make the next word with your letter cards.

Let's build this set of words again. This time your teacher will not tell you which letters to change. Let's try one together: Make the word hot <pause>. Now change hot to hotter. Which sound is different? Which letter will be different?

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about the sun and the seasons. First, look at these four pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. winter <pause>, snow <pause>, snowman <pause>, summer <pause>, trees <pause>, spring <pause>, flowers <pause>, fall <pause>, umbrella <pause>, leaves. Look at the picture of winter. Can you describe the weather happening in the picture?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about the sun and the seasons. The word is tilted. Tilted means “leaned or tipped.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, tilted>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words replace and tilted>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “The Sun and the Seasons.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about the sun and the seasons? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this story is "The Contest.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: The Contest. You will read a story about a contest, or competition, between the sun and the wind.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this story: confident. Confident means feeling that you can do well or succeed at something. I am confident that I can teach you how to become better readers. What is something you feel confident you can do? What makes you feel this way?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, confident>

audio.transcription: Read the story. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
Find the word that describes who won the contest.
What made Wind feel confident that he would succeed and win the contest? Find the sentences that answer this question.
How did Wind try to win the contest? Why didn’t his plan work? How did Sun win the contest using a more gentle approach?
Tell about a time when you competed in a contest or competition. What happened?
You can reread this story during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.

Write to Deepen Comprehension: Draw a picture to remember the important details in the story. Label the details, such as Sun, Wind, man, coat, and cloud. <pause> Use the drawing to retell the story to a partner. <pause> Then, write your retelling.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

slides.title: Morphology: Difference Between Prefixes and Suffixes

audio.transcription: What is the difference between prefixes and suffixes? Adding a prefix or suffix can can change a word's meaning and its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. Knowing the meanings of prefixes and suffixes can help you determine the meanings of words.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words in one column: untrue (with "un" underlined), dislike (with "dis" underlined), replay (with "re" underlined); and the following words in a second column: careless (with "less" underlined), writer (with "er" underlined), longest (with "est" underlined)>

audio.transcription: The difference between a prefix and a suffix is where they are added to a base word.
Remember, a prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word. Add the prefix "un" to the beginning of the word "true." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word true and the phonics/syllable card "un">

audio.transcription: untrue. <pause> The prefix "un" means “not” or “the opposite of,” therefore, untrue means “not true.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word true and the phonics/syllable card "un", under them, show the word "untrue">

audio.transcription: A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. Add the suffix "less" to the end of the word "care." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the word care and the phonics/syllable card for "less">

audio.transcription: careless. <pause> The suffix "less" means “no” or “without,” therefore, careless means “without care.”
audio.notes: <visual: show the word care and the phonics/syllable card for "less", under them, show the word "careless">

audio.transcription: Determine whether the following words contain a prefix or a suffix.
audio.notes: <visual: show the following words: teacher, quickly, unable, greatest, review, hopeful, shiny, disconnect>

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 9. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 8 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the story “The Contest.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 8 spread>

audio.transcription: Review Phonics Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show phonics cards>

audio.transcription: Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster.
Say the sound or sounds for each phonics card you see.
Review Word Cards
audio.notes: <visual: Show High-Frequency Word Cards>

audio.transcription: Let’s review some words. Say the word for each high-frequency word card you see.
Now, let’s try again—but this time faster. I’ll mix the cards.
Finally, find the card for the word I say. Listen carefully.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the pocket chart and word>

audio.transcription: Multimodal mini-lesson. Comparative suffixes "er" and "est." A suffix is a word part added to the end of a word. It can change the word's meaning and sometimes its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. The suffix "er" is used to compare two things. The suffix "est" is used to compare three of more things.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "er" and "est">

audio.transcription: Some words need spelling changes when adding a suffix. Listen as I read the following word: "tasty." Before adding suffix "er" to the end of "tasty," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "er." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: tasty tasty-y+i tasti+er tastier (in please show the "er" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "tastier." <pause> The suffix "er" is used to compare two things.
Before adding suffix "est" to the end of "tasty," first change the letter "y" to "i." Then add "est." What is the new word?
audio.notes: <visual: show the following in the order listed: tasty tasty-y+i tasti+est tastiest (please show the "est" in red font)>

audio.transcription: "tastiest." <pause> The suffix "est" is used to compare three or more things.
Blend Words: Let's blend some words to practice what we've learned. Read each word as your teacher taps on it. Say the word nice and loud.
audio.notes: <visual: show the blend words table>

audio.transcription: Select two words from the list. Write a sentence for each word.

Listen to each word your teacher says. Write the word. If you need help, tap the sounds or use your sound boxes and counters to break up the word sound by sound. Then think about the letter that stands for each sound.
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Let's start with these two words. Write the word kinder.
Now write the word quickest.
Now, write this sentence: The newest products are not always better than older ones.

Vocabulary Booster: Now we’ll listen to a text about underwater mountains and valleys. First, look at these two pictures. Listen as I read each word. Repeat the word after I say it. Mt. Everest <pause>, Mariana Trench <pause>, sky <pause>, ocean. Look at Mt. Everest and Mariana Trench in the picture. How are these places alike or different?
audio.notes: <visual: show vocabulary card>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about underwater mountains and valleys. The word is collide. Collide means “crash into each other.”
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the word, collide>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher introduces another important word.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the vocabulary card and the words collide and outer>

audio.transcription: Now listen to “Mountains and Valleys Under the Sea.”
Do you have any wonderings or questions about underwater mountains and valleys? Let’s write them down. We can look for answers as we read the stories in this unit.

Apply to Reading and Writing: Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 24 Student Book. The title of this text is "Earth's Changing Mountains.” Point to each word as you read the title with me: Earth's Changing Mountains. This text explains how natural forces change the shape and size of mountains over time.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the student book cover and story>

audio.transcription: Let’s learn an important word we will use to talk about this text: transform. Transform means to change in form, shape, or appearance. When it rains, a field of dirt may transform into mud. What is something in nature you have seen transform? How did its shape or appearance change?
audio.notes: <visual: Show the story and the word, transform>

audio.transcription: Read the text. Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
How are mountains different in size than other landforms? Find the word that answers the question.
What are some other examples of landforms? Find the sentence that answers the question.
What causes mountains to transform, or change, over time? How can you tell the difference between an older mountain and a younger mountain?
People transform over time, too! In what ways might you change in the next ten years?
You can reread this text during independent work time or at home. Tomorrow you will also reread it as a warm-up to the day’s lesson.
Write to Deepen Comprehension: List two to three facts they learned about mountains and how they change. <pause> Draw a picture to accompay your list.
audio.notes: <visual: Show the writing journal>

toc.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds
Morphology: Difference Between Prefixes and Suffixes

audio.transcription: Welcome to Benchmark Phonics, Level 3, Unit 24, Lesson 10. Let’s start by gathering your lesson materials. You'll need your Student Book for Unit 24.
audio.notes: <visual: book cover>

audio.transcription: Warm-Up: Review and Repetition. Reread to Build Fluency. Turn to Lesson 9 in your Unit 24 Student Book. Whisper read the story “Earth’s Changing Mountains.” Your teacher will listen in and help you as needed.
audio.notes: <visual: Student Book Lesson 9 spread>

audio.transcription: Let's make a word ladder. I will give you a clue for each word to write on the word ladder.
audio.notes: <visual: empty word ladder with 6 rungs>

audio.transcription: This word means the opposite of empty.
Add a suffix to full to make a word that describes a bag with the most items in it.
Replace the base word in fullest to make a word that describes a tree that is the least tall.
Replace the suffix in shortest to make a word that means the opposite of taller.
Replace the base word in shorter to make a word that means the opposite of dirtier.
Replace the base word in cleaner to make a word that means the opposite of lighter.
Now your teacher will ask you to read and write some words to check on your progress. Congratulations on all your hard work in Unit 24!

slides.title: Build Phonemic Awareness: Delete Initial and Final Sounds

audio.transcription: Listen as I say the following word: couch
audio.notes: <visual: show Phonemic Awareness image>

audio.transcription: Say the word couch without the beginning sound /k/. What's the new word? <pause> ouch
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Now let's delete the ending sound of a word. Listen as I say the following word: date
Say the word date without the ending sound /t/. What's the new word? <pause> day
Repeat the routine. Listen as your teacher says with the following words and sounds.
Let's do some more work with this unit's high-frequency words. Look at the high-frequency words.
audio.notes: <visual: covered, cried, figure, horse, money, products, questions, since, usually, voice>

audio.transcription: Listen as your teacher reads a high-frequency word from the list. Point to the word. Read the word. Spell the the word aloud.

Now build each high-frequency word using letter cards. Then work with a partner. Take turns scrambling the letters in the words. Rebuild each word. Watch as your teacher models scrambling and rebuilding the word "figure."
audio.notes: <visual: pocket chart with 3rd word spelled out with letter cards: figure>

slides.title: Morphology: Difference Between Prefixes and Suffixes

audio.transcription: Let's review the difference between prefixes and suffixes. Adding a prefix or suffix can can change a word's meaning and its part of speech, or how it is used in a sentence. A prefix is a word part added to the beginning of a word and a suffix is a word part added to the end of a word.
audio.notes: <visual: show the phonics/syllable cards for "re" and "ful">

audio.transcription: Listen as I read the following words: "play" <pause> "replay" <pause> "playful." Identify the base word in "replay" and "playful" and tell how the prefix or suffix change the word’s meaning.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words "play" "replay" and "playful">

audio.transcription: Identify whether each of the following words contain a prefix or a suffix.
audio.notes: <visual: show the words likely, smallest, disobey, speaker, smaller, rewrite, helpful, unhappy, harmless, rebuild, runny, preview>
